snippet.textDisplay:
Mark, water is actually diamagnetic. Have you seen the levitating frog. Some researchers floated a frog in a research magnet. Water is repelled by a magnetic field. It is a very weak effect. The much stronger effect would the electrostatic attraction or repulsion (depending on the sign of the charge).
One way to show the diamagnetic property of water is to have a shallow container of water (nonmagnetic container) and shine a laser pointer so it reflects off the surface then you can move a strong magnet under the container and see how the reflection changes or Veratasium does a nice demonstration by moving a non-magnetic object (small and very light) that is floating on water. By placing a strong neodymium magnet above and to the side, a small depression is created on the surface of the water and the object slides into the depression.
The reason water is attracted to a static charge (like a balloon rubbed on fur or hair) is due mostly to ions in the water not the water itself, but it's almost entirely due to electrostatics not magnetics.
snippet.textOriginal:
Mark, water is actually diamagnetic. Have you seen the levitating frog. Some researchers floated a frog in a research magnet. Water is repelled by a magnetic field. It is a very weak effect. The much stronger effect would the electrostatic attraction or repulsion (depending on the sign of the charge).
One way to show the diamagnetic property of water is to have a shallow container of water (nonmagnetic container) and shine a laser pointer so it reflects off the surface then you can move a strong magnet under the container and see how the reflection changes or Veratasium does a nice demonstration by moving a non-magnetic object (small and very light) that is floating on water. By placing a strong neodymium magnet above and to the side, a small depression is created on the surface of the water and the object slides into the depression.
The reason water is attracted to a static charge (like a balloon rubbed on fur or hair) is due mostly to ions in the water not the water itself, but it's almost entirely due to electrostatics not magnetics.

snippet.textDisplay: If you could simulate Earth's gravity using centripetal force in space, then you can use any old scale you have here on earth. More specifically you would need to simulate the acceleration due to gravity near Earths surface which is the 9.8 m/s^2. This can be done with a ship that has a piece that rotates, and one way to simulating this is by having a small radius, and a good size velocity (I.e. a 4 meter radius yields a 6.3 m/s velocity).
snippet.textOriginal: If you could simulate Earth's gravity using centripetal force in space, then you can use any old scale you have here on earth. More specifically you would need to simulate the acceleration due to gravity near Earths surface which is the 9.8 m/s^2. This can be done with a ship that has a piece that rotates, and one way to simulating this is by having a small radius, and a good size velocity (I.e. a 4 meter radius yields a 6.3 m/s velocity).

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Mark! Just first wanted to say I love the videos!

How do astronauts weigh themselves in space?
Shot in the dark here. I remember in high school physics they pounded the chant of "every force has an equal and opposite force" in my head. Oh yeah, and F=ma. Maybe if they had something of known weight, they could float with the item and push it away from themselves. The ratio of the speeds at which the astronaut and the item moved should be equal to the ratio of their weights?

It may be cheating to already have a weight benchmark but then maybe they could fill up a container with water (since volume is still measurable in space and they know the density of water) and do the same experiment.

Doesn't seem like the best use of water in space though, but I'm sure they can re-use it later! Plus, it would be pretty funny to see astronauts launching themselves away from massive buckets of water. Dear god, what has my mental model become.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey Mark! Just first wanted to say I love the videos!

How do astronauts weigh themselves in space?
Shot in the dark here. I remember in high school physics they pounded the chant of "every force has an equal and opposite force" in my head. Oh yeah, and F=ma. Maybe if they had something of known weight, they could float with the item and push it away from themselves. The ratio of the speeds at which the astronaut and the item moved should be equal to the ratio of their weights?

It may be cheating to already have a weight benchmark but then maybe they could fill up a container with water (since volume is still measurable in space and they know the density of water) and do the same experiment.

Doesn't seem like the best use of water in space though, but I'm sure they can re-use it later! Plus, it would be pretty funny to see astronauts launching themselves away from massive buckets of water. Dear god, what has my mental model become.

snippet.textDisplay:
"How do astronauts weigh themselves when they are weightless and floating in space?"

Easy, they use the "Watermeloninator" which launches a watermelon at their center of gravity (mid section) where an astronauts equal and opposite reaction can be measured (F=ma) to calculate their weight on earth.
snippet.textOriginal:
"How do astronauts weigh themselves when they are weightless and floating in space?"

Easy, they use the "Watermeloninator" which launches a watermelon at their center of gravity (mid section) where an astronauts equal and opposite reaction can be measured (F=ma) to calculate their weight on earth.

snippet.textDisplay: You can't weight anything in freefall, but your mass remains regardless. The more massive an object is the harder it is to accelerate, so I'm guessing they have some device that pushes them and measures how far they went with a constant known force being applied. I'm betting there are more than one way of determining ones mass on the ISS, or "in" the ISS, as they aren't "on" anything, unless you count an orbital trajectory as a thing which you can be "on", but that's just a quirk of language.
snippet.textOriginal: You can't weight anything in freefall, but your mass remains regardless. The more massive an object is the harder it is to accelerate, so I'm guessing they have some device that pushes them and measures how far they went with a constant known force being applied. I'm betting there are more than one way of determining ones mass on the ISS, or "in" the ISS, as they aren't "on" anything, unless you count an orbital trajectory as a thing which you can be "on", but that's just a quirk of language.

snippet.textDisplay:
Answer: They have some type of loaded spring that pushes with a known force, and the astronauts are pushed from that spring, and they measure the velocity the astronaut flies away.
Then you just do momentum divided by velocity to get mass.
That's all I can think of, but I guess that can't be the most accurate because astronauts are not rigid bodies, so some momentum will be lost due to deformation.
But then, if you "lock" your joints and attempt to be as rigid as possible, you may be able to reduce the deformation to acceptable limits?
Or they could enter some kind of pod with a known mass, and the pod is pushed with the spring. I think this should reduce the momentum lost due to deformation.
snippet.textOriginal:
Answer: They have some type of loaded spring that pushes with a known force, and the astronauts are pushed from that spring, and they measure the velocity the astronaut flies away.
Then you just do momentum divided by velocity to get mass.
That's all I can think of, but I guess that can't be the most accurate because astronauts are not rigid bodies, so some momentum will be lost due to deformation.
But then, if you "lock" your joints and attempt to be as rigid as possible, you may be able to reduce the deformation to acceptable limits?
Or they could enter some kind of pod with a known mass, and the pod is pushed with the spring. I think this should reduce the momentum lost due to deformation.

snippet.textDisplay: like on earth, to measure mass in space you need to compare the object you wish to measure against an object of known mass. however, the lack of gravity makes it a lot more interesting to actually perform this comparison. one method you could use is to simply compare inertia by having one object push the other with a known force and see how fast the object of known mass moves relative to the object being measured, assuming zero relative starting speed. another method you could use is to attach the astronaut to the end of a pole of known mass distribution then spin it along an axis perpendicular to the axis of the pole and measure the center of rotation.
snippet.textOriginal: like on earth, to measure mass in space you need to compare the object you wish to measure against an object of known mass. however, the lack of gravity makes it a lot more interesting to actually perform this comparison. one method you could use is to simply compare inertia by having one object push the other with a known force and see how fast the object of known mass moves relative to the object being measured, assuming zero relative starting speed. another method you could use is to attach the astronaut to the end of a pole of known mass distribution then spin it along an axis perpendicular to the axis of the pole and measure the center of rotation.

snippet.textDisplay:
Answer to question:
Answer 1: Maybe astronauts go into a spinning room like a ring. This creates artificial gravity and they can use the weigth equation F = mg to determine their mass but with the centrifugal force.
Answer 2: they count the number of protons and neutrons in their body(joke).
Answer 3: they put a scale on the wall and jump off it. The scale tells their weight (this might not be accurate though)
Answer 4: they push themselves against the wall? Or use big rubber bands that are stuck to the floor and pull them while they are on the scale.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Adhesion is only half the reason for capillary action. Cohesion is the other half. Adhesion gets the molecules of a liquid to adhere to channels made of other molecules, and cohesion gets other molecules of the liquid to follow those that adhere. The molecules that adhere lead and the molecules that cohere follow. You need both working together to get a flow with capillary action.
snippet.textOriginal: Adhesion is only half the reason for capillary action. Cohesion is the other half. Adhesion gets the molecules of a liquid to adhere to channels made of other molecules, and cohesion gets other molecules of the liquid to follow those that adhere. The molecules that adhere lead and the molecules that cohere follow. You need both working together to get a flow with capillary action.

snippet.textDisplay: They measure the time they stay afloat.

snippet.textDisplay: As you said in the first episode, heavier things are more difficult to move. And astronauts even though they don't have weight on space, they have mass. So if you use a device that moves with a certain speed, astronauts could "ride" this device and calculate their mass because the device would slow down.
snippet.textOriginal: As you said in the first episode, heavier things are more difficult to move. And astronauts even though they don't have weight on space, they have mass. So if you use a device that moves with a certain speed, astronauts could "ride" this device and calculate their mass because the device would slow down.
